Based on the provided sources, erosion resistance is a critical design consideration for downhole tools and components exposed to high-velocity fluids, abrasive particulates, and mechanical wear. The sources discuss achieving erosion resistance through specific material selection and geometric design configurations.
Material Selection
To withstand erosion caused by high-pressure fluids or abrasive contact with rock formations, components are often fabricated from specific hard and durable materials:
• Tungsten Carbide and Ultrahard Materials: Components subject to high erosion, such as the retainer elements in ball catcher tools, may be formed from tungsten carbide to limit erosion caused by high-velocity fluid flow,. Similarly, drill bit heads are often formed from wear and/or erosion-resistant materials, such as tungsten carbide infiltrated with a binder (e.g., nickel, cobalt, or copper-based),. Substrates for cutting elements may be formed of cemented carbides, such as tungsten carbide, titanium carbide, or chromium carbide.
• High-Pressure Body Materials: For cutting bits designed to convey fluid at pressures greater than 40 kpsi, the high-pressure body may be constructed from erosion-resistant materials such as high-strength steel, low-carbon steel, superalloys, Maraging steel, tungsten carbide, or polycrystalline diamond compact (PDC) to withstand the movement of the high-pressure fluid,.
• Processed Materials: Centralizers used in borehole assemblies may be manufactured using processed materials (e.g., via severe plastic deformation) to enhance wear resistance, thereby reducing surface damage and corrosion fatigue.
Geometric and Structural Design
Design geometry is utilized to deflect fluid flow and protect vulnerable components from direct erosive forces:
• Angled Surfaces: In ball catcher tools, the front surface of a retractable ball retainer element is designed with an acute angle (e.g., 20 to 45 degrees) relative to the inside surface of the channel,. This angled orientation helps limit erosion of the retainer block and pivot pin caused by high-velocity fluid flow,.
• Flow Tubes: In gas lift valves, a flow tube can be utilized as a conduit for flow to prevent or inhibit the flow from eroding or damaging seals or seal surfaces.
• Protective Covers and Shaping: In downhole pressure intensifier components, access windows may be sealed with covers shaped specifically to ensure good fluid flow and reduce erosion within the internal passages. Additionally, removable plates may be used to cover compartments within tools to limit fluid flow into void spaces, thereby reducing erosion of internal components like pivot pins,.
• Component Positioning: In drill bits, configuring the bit so that the ultrahard layer of a cutting element engages the rock formation—rather than the substrate—reduces friction and prevents material loss of the substrate due to erosion and wear. Furthermore, placing reinforcement rings formed of tough, ductile materials at connection portions can strengthen the bit against fracture, complementing the erosion-resistant materials used for the bit head,.
